revision.text: Hello and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]! Here are some tips to help you get started: * You should sign your name on Talk and vote pages using four tildes, like this: ~~~~. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * If you're a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]] to bring the material over in compliance with the GFDL. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[WB:SL|Staff Lounge]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun! You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Staff lounge|Staff lounge]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or ask me personally on my talk page. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be an idea if you add this page to your "watchlist" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. Good luck! --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 13:16, 3 February 2007 (UTC) * [[Relationships/Sex]] I should fix this bias article. == [[Bicycles]] == Hi! Per the discussion at the Reading Room, I've decided to add a section on riding for beginners. Since you're also contributing to this book, could I get your input on whether [http://en.wikibooks.org/w/index.php?title=Bicycles&action=historysubmit&diff=2013458&oldid=2012589 this] or [http://en.wikibooks.org/w/index.php?title=Bicycles&diff=prev&oldid=2012589 this] is a better way to integrate the planned content (i.e., adding a direct beginner chapter versus splitting the book into two sections)? I can't decide which is better (or if there's an even better alternative). Cheers, [[User talk:Tempodivalse#top|'''''Tempodivalse''''']] 16:13, 7 January 2011 (UTC) {{talkback|User talk:Tempodivalse#RE: Bicycles}} [[User talk:Tempodivalse#top|'''''Tempodivalse''''']] 16:27, 8 January 2011 (UTC) == Dewikification == Removing red links is fine, but is it really necessary to remove the references too? – [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] [[User talk:Adrignola|discuss]] 03:31, 19 February 2011 (UTC) == Great work == [[File:WikiGnome.png|left]] I like what I see. Merge proposals, book splits. You're quite the [[w:Wikipedia:WikiGnome|WikiGnome]]! – [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] [[User talk:Adrignola|discuss]] 03:01, 5 March 2011 (UTC) :Thanks, I just like everything to be orderly. It seems I'll never run out of things to tinker with on this wiki. If you see any questionable decisions on my part, feel free to bring it up! I fear I can become too '''bold''' after an editing rampage. --[[User:Thereen|Thereen]] ([[User talk:Thereen|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Thereen|contribs]]) 21:16, 6 March 2011 (UTC) ==Viva intellectual freedom== [[http://en.wikibooks.org/w/index.php?title=Wikibooks%3AReading_room%2FProjects&action=historysubmit&diff=2103697&oldid=2095256]]20:56, 23 May 2011 (UTC) [[http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Wikibooks:Reading_room/Projects]] NPOV ergo AllPOV 20:57, 23 May 2011 (UTC) == Thanks! == Thanks! I think I'm the only one over at Russian, so it's nice to finally know I'm doing a good job! You seem to know your way around Wikibooks, so I had a couple of questions, if I may... Is there a way to see all the changes made to an entire wikibook, even if the pages aren't in your watchlist? [[User:DD 8630|DD 8630]] ([[User talk:DD 8630|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/DD 8630|contribs]]) 18:14, 20 June 2011 (UTC) ==Thank you for the welcome== Hi Thereen. Just wanted to thank you for the nice welcome message and the help offer. --[[User:XanaG|XanaG]] ([[User talk:XanaG|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/XanaG|contribs]]) 22:57, 20 June 2011 (UTC) ==Hello!== Thanks! I am really excited to help contribute to the Canadian History Wikibook! I have gone through pages and fixed a lot of the formatting. [[User:Mitchturn|Mitchturn]] ([[User talk:Mitchturn|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Mitchturn|contribs]]) 04:09, 11 November 2011 (UTC) ==Hello== Thereen, Thank you for your suggestion for merging the two books. I tried to do that in the beginning, but didn't see how I could do it. You see, the way that book was put together, feels as if someone had very little understanding of the language and just put down all they knew in a random order. There is no organization to that book. I don't want to delete it, for fear of conflict with the person who made that page. I just don't see how I could conjoin the two books, so i hope that makes sense. Also, I am planning to create a series called the ''Dedicated Learner Series'', and the Hawaiian book is number one, therefore I cannot change the title of the book. I hope you understand. Thanks for the compliments! And if you know of anyone who would be willing to have a conversation about languages, please have them start a discussion; I would love to talk with them! [[User:Master tongue|Master tongue]] ([[User talk:Master tongue|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Master tongue|contribs]]) 06:24, 27 November 2011 (UTC) :Thank you for your quick response! Your fear of conflict with the primary authors of [[Hawaiian]] is (to my mind) not necessary. In the last 30 days, you appear to be the only user making content edits to that book. The talk page has been inactive since 2008, and there is no strict guideline in place for further development to the book. It would seem that any primary authors that once edited the book are no longer active. Also, wikibooks is perfectly suited to collaborations between authors, as well as shifts in content and focus. In short, I see no problem with you imposing your planned structure and content on the wikibook titled [[Hawaiian]]. The pre-existing content could be worked into your plans as dialogue snippets or appendixes with vocabulary to learn. :Regarding your planned series, I am not sure that including the title of the series in each of your texts is the best course of action. I think it would be better if you were to acknowledge that each of the books you start are part of the "Dedicated Learner Series" on the content page of each book, rather than the title. Having simple titles, like [[Hawaiian]] makes your book more searchable, and therefore each book will reach more potential learners. --[[User:Thereen|Thereen]] ([[User talk:Thereen|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Thereen|contribs]]) 00:11, 28 November 2011 (UTC) ::Yes, I suppose that does make a lot of sense. I will try that now. Thank you for your input in this decision. I apriciate all of your advise, and hope we can collaborate in the future on similar problems. It might take a while for me to transfer things over and change links, etc. Tell me what you think when it's all done. I would greatly accept your oppinions, as I have on this one. Thanks! [[User:Master tongue|Master tongue]] ([[User talk:Master tongue|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Master tongue|contribs]]) 01:54, 28 November 2011 (UTC) == [[Canadian LGBT History]] == I have imported your page from Wikipedia as you requested. It will need to be dewikied and made into a book. Good luck. --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 11:06, 10 December 2011 (UTC) == Thanks For Your Welcome == Thank you so much for welcoming me and suggesting some educational and creative arts categories of books. [[User:Demarshall|Demarshall]] ([[User talk:Demarshall|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Demarshall|contribs]]) 06:47, 24 December 2011 (UTC) == Thanks again - Yes, I Do! == Thanks again - Yes, I Do! Enjoy Editing Ebooks! I have done it for Gutenberg in the past. :-) [[User:Demarshall|Demarshall]] ([[User talk:Demarshall|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Demarshall|contribs]]) 09:08, 24 December 2011 (UTC) == Rewikification == You can request a fix of wikipedia's links (rewikification) at [[User talk:Hethrir]]. Wikilinks are good metadata. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 12:11, 24 December 2011 (UTC) :Thank you so much! This bot will save me hours. Adding it to my toolkit.--[[User:Thereen|Thereen]] ([[User talk:Thereen|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Thereen|contribs]]) 21:25, 24 December 2011 (UTC) == Talkback == {{Talkback|Quintucket|Hello}}
'''ALT+EKEY''' - Start/stop EditMode. Alternative hotkey: '''TAB'''.<noinclude>{{BookCat}}</noinclude>

'''CTRL+FKEY''' - Sort Faces. The faces of the active Mesh Object are sorted, based on the current view in the 3DWindow. The leftmost face first, the rightmost last. The sequence of faces is important for the Build Effect (AnimButtons).<noinclude>{{BookCat}}</noinclude>

*'''CTRL+FKEY''' - {{Blender 3D: HotKeys/Pre2.5}} Flip faces, selected triangular faces are paired and common edge of each pair swapped. *'''CTRL+FKEY''' - {{Blender 3D: HotKeys/Post2.5}} Face specials.<noinclude>{{BookCat}}</noinclude>
Apolgies - looked like blanking and I moved too quickly. I have reverted back to your version - sorry --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 14:32, 3 February 2007 (UTC)

'''ALT+FKEY''' - Beauty Fill. The edges of all the selected triangular faces are switched in such a way that equally sized faces are formed. This operation is 2D; various layers of polygons must be filled in succession. The Beauty Fill can be performed immediately after a Fill.<noinclude>{{BookCat}}</noinclude>

'''SHIFT+FKEY''' - Fill selected. All selected vertices that are bound by edges and form a closed polygon are filled with triangular faces. Holes are automatically taken into account. This operation is 2D; various layers of polygons must be filled in succession.<noinclude>{{BookCat}}</noinclude>

'''SHIFT+BKEY''' - Render Border. This only works in Camera ViewMode. Draw a rectangle to render a smaller cut-out of the standard window frame. If the option DisplayButtons->Border is ON, a box is drawn with red and black lines.<noinclude>{{BookCat}}</noinclude>

'''BBQ sam-chang-bak''' is a very simple [[Cookbook:Barbecuing|barbecue]] seasoning recipe for pork meat.
==Ingredients== * 3 ''katis'' (1.8-2 kg) (4 lbs) of [[Cookbook:Pork|pork meat]] (sam-chang-bak) * 5 tablespoons of char-siu sauce * 5 tablespoons of [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * [[Cookbook:Pepper|pepper]] * A few drops of tenderizer
==Procedure== # Sprinkle the tenderizer on the meat, then mix the rest of the ingredients together with the meat. # Barbecue!
[[Category:Pork recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Barbecue recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Southeast Asian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

'''BKEY BKEY''' - {{Blender 3D: HotKeys/Pre2.5}} Circle Select. Use '''NUM+''' to increase, '''NUM-''' to decrease, or '''MW''' to adjust the circle size. Drag over vertices/edges/faces with '''LMB''' to add them to selection, '''MMB''' to remove them from selection. Leave Circle Select with '''RMB''' or '''ESC'''.<noinclude>{{BookCat}}</noinclude>
'''ALT+BKEY''' - Select portion of viewing area to only be visible.<noinclude>{{BookCat}}</noinclude>

'''Suriname''' is a South American country which has Guyana, Brazil and French Guyana as its neighbors. It is the only Dutch speaking country in South America, and it considers itself a member of the Caribbean. Suriname has been a member of the Caribbean community (Caricom) since 1994. Suriname is a mix of different cultures including, Dutch, French, English, Spanish, Javanese, Chinese, Creole, Indian and many others. The cuisine of Suriname is therefore also very diverse and very wonderful. {{Wikipedia|Suriname}}
== Appetizers ==
*[[cookbook:samosa|samosa]] *[[cookbook:kipspek|kipspek]]
== Soups == *[[cookbook:Peanut soup|peanut soup]] *[[cookbook:Pea Soup|pea soup]] *[[cookbook:soato|soato]]
== Main dishes ==
*[[cookbook:Moksi Alesie|moksi aleisi]] *[[cookbook:pom|pom]] *[[cookbook:pastei|pastei]]

{{recipesummary|Confection recipes|Makes 16|1 hour|2|[[File:Brownies recipe.png|thumb| Rich Chocolate brownies]] }} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|Vegetarian Cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|Holiday Recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Dessert|Dessert]] Double Chocolate Brownies
==Ingredients== * ⅓ cup [[Cookbook:Butter|unsalted butter]] * ¾ cup [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * ¼ cup [[Cookbook:Water|water]] * one 12 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]] package dark or bittersweet [[Cookbook:Chocolate Chips|chocolate chips]], divided in half * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Vanilla|vanilla]] * ¾ [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] [[Cookbook:Flour|all purpose flour]] * ¼ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] * ¼ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 2 large [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] [[Cookbook:Nut|nuts]] ''(optional)'' ==Procedure== # Let the eggs and butter sit out for 30 minutes to bring to room temperature. # Preheat oven to [[Cookbook:Oven temperatures|325°F]]. # In a small bowl sift in the flour with the baking soda and salt then set aside. # In a small [[Cookbook:Saucepan|saucepan]] combine butter, sugar, and water. Bring just to a [[Cookbook:Boil|boil]] then remove from heat. # Add ½ of the chocolate chips (6 oz) and vanilla. Stir until smooth and shiny. # Transfer the chocolate mixture into a large bowl. # Add eggs one at a time [[Cookbook:Beating|beating]] well after each addition. # Gradually blend in flour mixture. # Stir in remaining chocolate chips and nuts if desired. # Spread in a greased 9" square pan. # Bake at 325°F for 30-35 minutes. # Cool completely before cutting into 2-1/4" squares. ==Tips, Notes, and Variations== * Substitute some or all of the flour with whole wheat flour. * To substantially reduce the fat and cholesterol substitute the two eggs with three egg whites. * Substitute the vanilla extract with ½ teaspoon almond extract or 2 teaspoon orange liquor. page.title: CAT-Tools/DéjàVu X/Does DVX run on Mac or Linux too?

revision.text:
== Mac OS X ==
No DejaVu version runs natively under Mac OS X. You have to use either a virtual machine solution or an API layer. These are known - so far: * Parallels (http://www.parallels.com/), virtual machine, known to work with Windows + DVX installed, good Mac integration. DejaVu Dongle works. * CrossOver Office (http://www.codeweavers.com/), API layer, runs, has some issues to be solved before working as it should. Dongle doesn't work yet. Please see http://www.codeweavers.com/compatibility/browse/name?app_id=205 Feel free to contribute!
== Linux ==
No DejaVu version runs natively under Linux. You have to use either a virtual machine solution or an API layer. These are known - so far: * CrossOver Office (http://www.codeweavers.com/), API layer, has some issues to be solved before working as it should. Dongle doesn't work yet. Please see http://www.codeweavers.com/compatibility/browse/name?app_id=205 Feel free to contribute!
== Unix ==
So far, nobody seems to have tested running DejaVu on any Unix system, but with CrossOver available for both Mac OS X, Linux and Solaris, and Mac OS X being built on BSD, it might work (e. g. with Parallels). Possibly even via thin client, which may however run into dongle issues.
== Notes on technology ==
* Virtual machine: You install Windows into a virtual machine, which is software that behaves to Windows as if it were PC hardware. Any other software you want to run is installed "as usual" in that Windows system. The current development goes towards making the operating systems aware of being run in a virtual machine, which might enhance performance and get rid of some hardware access problems, like e. g. dongle handling. * API layer: Presents the software you want to run with the interface towards the operating system it was made for and expects, in this case Windows. The other side of the interface is in this case connected to Linux, Mac OS X, Solaris UNIX etc., rather than leading to Windows. This approach rids you of having to use Windows altogether, and of introducing an additional layer for the virtual machine. Unfortunately, it instead introduces problems for software that wants direct hardware access, most notably for the dongle - so far.
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Soup recipes|8|Cook 1.5 hours|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Colombia|Cuisine of Colombia]]
'''Ajiaco''' is a quintessential dish from Bogotá, [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Colombia|Colombia]].
==Ingredients==
===Soup:===
* 1 whole skin-on bone-in [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] breast (approximately 750[[Cookbook:G|g]]) * 1 [[Cookbook:L|l]] chicken broth * 1 [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], peeled * 2 [[Cookbook:Scallion|scallions]] (white part and first 2 cm of green) * 2 [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]], peeled * 4 [[Cookbook:Clove|cloves]] [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], peeled * 1 [[Cookbook:Bay Leaf|bay leaf]] * 3 [[Cookbook:ML|ml]] dried [[Cookbook:Thyme|thyme]] * 2 [[Cookbook:ML|ml]] ground [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]] * 4 sprigs fresh [[Cookbook:Cilantro|cilantro]] * 10 [[Cookbook:Black Pepper|black peppercorns]] * 5 [[Cookbook:ML |ml]] tomato paste * .5 [[Cookbook:Kg|kg]] small yellow [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]]. peeled * .5 [[Cookbook:Kg|kg]] small purple [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]]. peeled * .5 [[Cookbook:Kg|kg]] mashing [[Cookbook:Potato|potatoes]], peeled and sliced 2 cm thickness * 1 [[Cookbook:L|l]] water * 2 [[Cookbook:ML|ml]] of beef bullion granules * .25 [[Cookbook:ML|ml]] of frozen [[Cookbook:Peas|peas]]
===Garnishes:===
* 4 ears of [[Cookbook:Corn|corn]], quartered lengthwise and cooked * 10 [[Cookbook:ML|ml]] of whipping cream mixed with 10 [[Cookbook:ML|ml]] of créme fraíche * 2 ripe but firm Hass [[Cookbook:Avocado|avocados]], peeled, pitted and cut into eight slices right before serving * 10 [[Cookbook:ML|ml]] of finely chopped [[Cookbook:Cilantro|cilantro]] * 5 - 10 [[Cookbook:ML|ml]] of pickled [[Cookbook:Caper|capers]]
==Procedure==
# Combine chicken, broth, onions, scallions, carrots, garlic, bay leaf, thyme, cumin, cilantro and peppercorns in large sauce pan and bring to a boil. Skim off froth as it rises. Reduce heat to low and cover when frothing finishes. # Remove and reserve chicken after it is cooked through (approximately 20 minutes). # Strain broth through sieve and return to pot, boil again over medium heat. Reserve carrots. # Add tomato paste and yellow and purple potatoes. Cover and cook until potatoes are soft (approximately 20 minutes). # While yellow and purple potatoes are cooking, boil sliced mashing potatoes in water and beef bullion in separate pot. Once boiling, reduce to medium heat until potatoes start to fall apart (approximately 30 minutes). # Drain and reserve a quarter of the slices and mash the rest of the sliced potatoes. Add mashed and sliced potatoes to soup. # Remove bones and skin from chicken and discard. Cut chicken into strips 1 cm wide and 3 cm long. # Add chicken and peas to soup and simmer for 5 minutes. Slice the carrots into .5 cm thick rounds and add back into soup. Salt to taste. # Serve hot with garnishes available.
==Notes, tips, and variations==
* If soup is too thick add boiling water in small amounts; the consistency should be like that of heavy cream. Soup will thicken as it cools.
[[Category:Soup recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Colombian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Meat recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{Chess Opening Theory/Position|= |Dutch Defence| |rd|nd|bd|qd|kd|bd|nd|rd|= |pd|pd|pd|pd|pd| |pd|pd|= | | | | | | | | |= | | | | | |pd| | |= | | |pl|pl| | | | |= | | | | | | | | |= |pl|pl| | |pl|pl|pl|pl|= |rl|nl|bl|ql|kl|bl|nl|rl|= || }} =Dutch Defence= Towards this move black has basically two typical set ups. *One is a fortress like position with pawn structure f5-e6-d5. This is called the Stonewall defence. This type of position is considered solid, but perhaps too static. *A dynamic choice is a Leningrad setup. The pawn structure is practically always g6-f5-d6. Black plays in this system, with only a few rare exceptions, his bishop to g7, knight to f6, and castles quickly. ==Theory table== {{ChessTable}}. '''1. d4 f5 2. c4'''
2 3 4 5 6 7
Leningrad ...

[[/2...e6|e6]]		 g3

{{ChessMid}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Wikipedia|Dutch Defence}} *[http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1085547 Example from 1989 of play in main line by current world champion Vladimir Kramnik] *[http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1143722 Example from 1992 of play in main line by Veselin Topalov] {{BCO2}} {{Chess Opening Theory/Footer}}

'''Deep Depression income-expenditure model - Keynesian Multipliers'''
One way to describe the economy is with the equation <math>Y~=~C~+~Z+~G</math> where <math>~Y</math> represents total income, <math>~C</math> represents consumption, and <math>~Z</math> represents investment (other than government investment, of course). If the economy under discussion is that of a country, <math>~Y</math> can be thought of as approximating the countries <math>~GNP</math>. We can think of consumption as a function of disposable income <math>C~=~\lambda(Y-T)</math> where <math>~T</math> is taxes where <math>~\lambda</math> is the Marginal Propensity to Consume.
The ''Marginal Propensity to Consume (MPC)'' is the rate of growth of consumption in terms of an increase in disposable income and is defined as the derivative of the consumption function, <math> \lambda~ = ~\frac{dC}{dY} </math>. Assuming all spending is divided evenly between consumption and savings, the ''Marginal Propensity to Save (MPS)'' is defined as the rate of growth in savings in terms of an increase in disposable income and is calculated as <math>MPS~ =~ 1-MPC </math>.
==Multipliers== ===GEM - Government expenditure multiplier=== The GEM considers the idea that since only a percentage of money that anyone receives is saved, and the rest is put back into the economy. So if the government gives someone a dollar (deficit spending), it will end up meaning that much more than a dollar will be added to the economy. One way to think about it is the GEM is the amount that <math>Y</math>, total income, changes as <math>G</math>, government expenditure changes. So we look at our formula with the consumption function included, we have:
<math>Y~=~\lambda(Y-T)+~Z+~G</math>
<math>\Rightarrow dY = \lambda dY+dG</math>
<math>\Rightarrow dY(1-MPC)=dG</math>
<math>\Rightarrow \frac{dY}{dG} = \frac{1}{1-MPC}</math>, which, in fact, gives,
<math>\Rightarrow GEM = \frac{dY}{dG} = \frac{1}{MPS}</math>
===TCM - Tax Cut Multiplier=== In this case, we want to know how much a change in the tax rate will affect total income. Our derivation follows the same lines as before. In this case we have:
<math>Y~= ~\lambda (Y-T)+~Z+~G</math>
<math>\Rightarrow dY = \lambda (dY-dT)</math>
<math>\Rightarrow dY=MPC(dY-dT)</math>
<math>\Rightarrow dY(1-MPC)=-MPC~dT</math>, which gives,
<math>\Rightarrow TCM = \frac{dY}{dT} = -\frac{MPC}{1-MPC} = -\frac{MPC}{MPS}</math>
In general, <math> |GEM| \geq |TCM| </math> since: <math> MPC \leq 1 </math>.
===BBM - Balanced Budget Multiplier=== This is a sort of combination of the previous two multipliers, where any change in spending corresponds to a change in tax rates, i.e. <math>dG ~= dT</math>. Now we can take the derivative of our equation with respect to all three variables.
<math>Y~=~\lambda~ (Y-T)+~Z+~G</math>
<math>\Rightarrow dY = \lambda(dY-dT)+dG </math>
<math>\Rightarrow dY=MPC(dY-dT)+dG</math>
<math>\Rightarrow dY(1-MPC)=-MPC~dT+dG </math>. Now we set <math>dG~=dT</math>
<math>\Rightarrow dY(1-MPC)=dT(1-MPC)</math>, which gives,
<math>\Rightarrow BBM = \frac{dY}{dT} = \frac{dY}{dG} = 1</math>
Thus if the we have a balanced budget with respect to government spending and taxation, total income will be unchanged.
===More information=== In general the theoretical multipliers are higher than the actual multipliers. Why? In general agents tend to want to smoothen their consumption over their lifetime, thus they do not respond fully to exogenous shocks. Taxes distort. The model is isolated from the outside world. Other reasons?
===References===
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]
see [[w:User:Mbimmler]]

revision.comment: Revert - this is a mess of bad wikilinking
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Meat recipes|6 to 8|1 hour|3}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Cuba|Cuban cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Caribbean cuisines|Caribbean cuisine]]
Cuban Picadillo
==Ingredients==
* 2 [[Cookbook:Pound|pounds]] [[Cookbook:Ground Beef|ground beef]] * ¼ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] [[Cookbook:Olive Oil|olive oil]], divided * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Dice|diced]] [[Cookbook:Onion|Oso Sweet onions]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Green Pepper|green pepper]], diced * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] * 1 15-[[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]] can [[Cookbook:Tomato Sauce|tomato sauce]] * 2 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoons]] ground [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin]] * 2 teaspoons dried [[Cookbook:Oregano|oregano]] * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Raisin|raisins]] * ½ cup chopped [[Cookbook:Olive|pimento-stuffed green olives]] * 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Vinegar|red wine vinegar]] * [[Cookbook:Salt|Salt]] and [[Cookbook:Pepper|fresh ground black pepper]] to taste
==Procedure==
# In large [[Cookbook:Skillet|skillet]], brown beef in 2 tablespoons olive oil over high heat; drain and reserve. # In same skillet, lightly brown onion, pepper, and garlic in remaining oil. # Add tomato sauce, cumin, and oregano; bring to [[Cookbook:Boil|boil]]. # Reduce heat and [[Cookbook:simmer|simmer]] 20 minutes, stirring occasionally, until mixture has thickened. # Stir in beef, raisins, olives and season to taste with salt and pepper. # Bring back to boil, simmer 10 minutes and serve over steamed rice with [[Cookbook:Sauté|sautéed]] sliced ripe [[Cookbook:Plantain|plantains]] and [[Cookbook:Black Beans|black beans]].
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* Make a double batch and freeze half for up to three months. Defrost in [[Cookbook:Microwave Oven|microwave oven]]. * Use Texmati rice, a hybrid of American long-grain rice with Indian basmati, for perfect, fluffy results.
[[Category:Cuban recipes|Picadillo, Cuban]] [[Category:Meat recipes|Picadillo, Cuban]] [[Category:Beef recipes|Picadillo, Cuban]] [[Category:Tomato recipes|Picadillo, Cuban]]

Three days after Germany invaded Poland on 1 September 1939, Britain and France declared war. At the time a large majority of Australia's population was of direct British descendants (After all Australia is a British nation)and opposed the German expansion; thus supporting Britain. After the British Government declared war, Prime Minister Menzies announced that ‘Australia was also at war’.
The Australian forces had a difficult decision to make: Defend Australian soil from a possible threat (from Japan), or to support the British forces in Europe. After Japan announced its neutrality and Britain reassured that its naval base in Singapore would stop any Japanese forces advancing; Australia almost completely committed all its forces to supporting the British.
A force and supply system was put into place by Prime Minister Menzies to help prepare the nation for war. The Royal Australian Navy was placed under the control of the British; the Army began recruiting and training men; the nation was preparing its self for war.
===Development Sources=== *http://www.awm.gov.au/atwar/ww2.htm *http://www.ww2australia.gov.au/ *http://www.anzacday.org.au/history/ww2/ww2main.html *http://www.anzacday.org.au/history/ww2/overview/ww2-01.html *http://www.ww2roll.gov.au/
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

revision.comment: New page: {{subst:welcome}} Thanks for editing the Muggles' Guide. Unfortunately we're not interested in listing popular fan ideas other things not based on actual fact. I've removed your reference...
revision.text:
Hello and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to help you get started: * You should sign your name on Talk and vote pages using four tildes, like this: ~~~~. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * If you're a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]] to bring the material over in compliance with the GFDL. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[WB:SL|Staff Lounge]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Staff lounge|Staff lounge]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or ask me personally on my talk page. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be an idea if you add this page to your "watchlist" so that you can see when any new information is posted there.
Good luck!
Thanks for editing the Muggles' Guide. Unfortunately we're not interested in listing popular fan ideas other things not based on actual fact. I've removed your references. Thanks. -[[User:Withinfocus|<font color="#000000">'''within'''</font>]][[User talk:Withinfocus|<font color="#7A7A7A">'''focus'''</font>]] 05:25, 4 February 2007 (UTC)

====Websites==== There are many good websites out there on the topic of QBasic. This is a list of the best sites:
[http://www.petesqbsite.com/ Petes QBasic Site]: This site is mostly aimed at people thinking about programming video games in QBasic.
[http://www.qbasic.com/classic/qbindex.html The QBasic Page]: This is a good site for getting source codes and programs for QBasic.
[http://www.qbasicnews.com/ QBasic News]: The most recent and up to date news on the QBasic community.
[http://www.tedfelix.com/qbasic/ QBasic Programming for Kids]: A good site for young people to start programming.

revision.comment: /* Some personal pronouns */ correction of translation
revision.text:
{{miskito_title|7|Inglis aisisma ki?|Do you speak English?|Lesson 6|Lesson 8}} ==''I am''== {{miskito_model| * Maria '''sna'''. * Mairin kum '''sna'''. * Yaptikam '''sna'''. * Tiara '''sna'''. * Bilwi ra '''sna'''. * Nahara '''sna'''. * Tuktan nani ba wal '''sna'''. * Umpira '''apia sna'''. * '''Yang''' nahara skul ra man wal '''sna'''. | * '''I am''' Maria. * '''I am''' a woman. * '''I am''' your mother. * '''I am''' young. * '''I am''' in Bilwi. * '''I am''' here. * '''I am''' with the children. * '''I am not''' poor. * '''I am''' here in the school with you. }} {{miskito_mini_exercise|Change the subject form '''witin''' to '''yang''': | # Witin waitna kum sa. # Witin nahara sa. # Witin umpira sa. # Witin utla ra sa. # Witin sirpi pali sa. # Witin skul ra apia sa. | # Yang waitna kum sna. # Yang nahara sna. # Yang umpira sna. # Yang utla ra sna. # Yang sirpi pali sna. # Yang skul ra apia sna. }} {{miskito_comment|'''Sna''' ''I am'', '''apia sna''' ''I am not''.}} {{miskito_note|Since these already express the first-person notion, it is not necessary to say '''yang''' ''I'' with them, although you can: '''(Yang) Jan sna''' ''I am John'', '''(Yang) yaptikam apia sna''' ''I am not your mother''.}}


==''You are''== {{miskito_model| * Jan '''sma'''. * Waitna kum '''sma'''. * Aisiki '''sma''' ki? * Tiara pali '''sma'''. * Tawan ra '''sma'''. * Anira '''sma''' ki? * Ya wal '''sma''' ki? * Umpira '''apia sma'''. * '''Man''' nahara skul ra yang wal '''sma'''. | * '''You are''' John. * '''You are''' a man. * '''Are you''' my father? * '''You are''' very young. * '''You are''' in the village. * Where '''are you'''? * Who '''are you''' with? * '''You are not''' poor. * '''You are''' here in the school with me. }} {{miskito_mini_exercise|Answer these questions, taking the words in parentheses as cues: | # Nahara sma ki? (au) # Yaptikam ba wal sma ki? (apia) # Anira sma? (skul) # Tuktan kum sma ki? (apia) # Aisikam anira sa? (tawan) | # Au, nahara sna. # Apia, yaptiki ba wal apia sna. # Skul ra sna. # Apia, tukan kum apia sna. # Aisiki tawan ra sa. }} {{miskito_comment|'''Sma''' ''you are'', '''apia sma''' ''you are not''.}} {{miskito_note|As with '''(yang) sna''', '''man''' ''you'' can be omitted with '''sma'''.}} {{miskito_comment|Forms of the present tense of '''kaia''' ''to be'' that you now know:}} {| cellspacing=0 cellpadding=6 align="center" | align="right" | first person (''I...'') | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''sna''' |- | align="right" | second person (''you...'') | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''sma''' |- | align="right" | third person (''she, he, they...''; also '''yawan''' ''we'' inclusive) | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''sa''' |}
==Some personal pronouns== {{miskito_model| * '''Yang''' utla ra sna. * '''Man''' sin utla ra sma. * '''Witin''' utla ra sa. * '''Witin nani''' sut utla ra sa! * '''Yawan''' utla ra sa. * Man '''yang wal''' sma. * Yang '''man wal''' sna. * Yawan '''witin wal''' sa. * Yawan '''witin nani wal''' sa. * Witin nani '''yawan wal''' sa. | * '''I''' am at home. * '''You''' are also at home. * '''She/He''' is at home. * '''They''' are all at home! * '''We''' (you and I) are at home. * You are '''with me'''. * I am '''with you'''. * We are '''with her/him'''. * We are '''with them'''. * They are '''with us'''. }} {{miskito_mini_exercise|Place '''yang, man''' or '''witin''' at the beginning of the sentence as appropriate: | # Anira sma? # Miriki apia sna. # Miskitu sa. # Prias watla ra sna. # Rum ra sma ki? # Sirpi pali sna. # Yaptiki wal apia sna. # Bahara sa. | # Man anira sma? # Yang Miriki apia sna. # Witin Miskitu sa. # Yang prias watla ra sna. # Man rum ra sma ki? # Yang sirpi pali sna. # Yang yaptiki wal apia sna. # Witin bahara sa. }} {{miskito_comment|You also now know the following personal pronouns:}} {| cellspacing=0 cellpadding=6 align="center" | align="right" | ''I'' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''yang''' |- | align="right" | ''you'' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''man''' |- | align="right" | ''she, he'' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''witin''' |- | align="right" | ''they'' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''witin nani''' |- | align="right" | ''we'' inclusive, i.e. ''you and I'' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''yawan''' |} {{miskito_comment|These pronouns may function in different grammatical roles in the sentence: as subject, object, complement of a postposition...}}
==The present tense== {{miskito_model| * Miskitu '''aisisna'''. * Inglis sin '''aisisma''' ki? — Au, yang Inglis pain '''aisisna'''. * Witin Ispail baman '''aisisa'''. * Dia '''daukisma'''? — Yang utla wina '''takisna'''. * Dia muni '''inisma'''? — Yaptiki '''plikisna'''. * Man wark '''takisma'''? — Apia, Miskitu bila baman lan '''takisna'''. * Naha wina tuktiki nani ba ra pain '''kaikisna'''. * Tuktan nani ba ra '''walisma'''? Au, witin ra '''walisna'''. | * '''I speak''' Miskito. * '''Do you speak''' English too? — Yes, '''I speak''' English well. * She/He only '''speaks''' Spanish. * What '''are you doing'''? — '''I am going out''' of the house. * Why '''are you crying'''? — '''I am looking for''' my mother. * '''Are you working'''? — No, '''I am''' only '''learning''' Miskito. * From here '''I see''' my children well. * '''Do you hear''' the children? Yes, '''I hear''' them. }} {{miskito_mini_exercise|Fill the blank with an appropriate present tense form of the verb whose infinitive is given. | # Yang Inglis __________. (aisaia) # Man yul ba __________ ki? (kaikaia) # Witin aisiki wal __________. (wark takaia) # Yang yul nani ba __________. (walaia) # Man tuktan kum __________. (kaia) # Yang Miskitu bila baman __________. (aisaia) # Man yaura __________? (plikaia) # Witin sap wina __________. (takaia) | # Yang Inglis aisisna. # Man yul ba kaikisma ki? # Witin aisiki wal wark takisa. # Yang yul nani ba walisna. # Man tuktan kum sma. # Yang Miskitu bila baman aisisna. # Man yaura plikisma? # Witin sap wina takisa. }} {{miskito_comment|It was explained before that a verb form such as '''daukisa''' comes from '''dauki''' (a participle, ''doing'') and '''sa''' ''is''. In order to say ''I am doing, you are doing..'', and also ''I do, you do...'', the appropriate form of ''to be'' is placed after the ''i''-form (e.g. '''dauki'''), and this gives us the regular present tense, with these endings:}} {| cellspacing=0 cellpadding=6 align="center" | align="right" | first person | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''-isna''' |- | align="right" | second person | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''-isma''' |- | align="right" | third person, ''yawan'' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''-isa''' |} {{miskito_comment|Examples:}} {| cellspacing=0 cellpadding=6 align="center" | | '''''daukaia''' do'' | '''''kaikaia''' see'' | '''''pulaia''' play'' | '''''aisaia''' speak'' |- | align="right" | 1 | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''daukisna''' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''kaikisna''' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''pulisna''' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''aisisna''' |- | align="right" | 2 | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''daukisma''' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''kaikisma''' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''pulisma''' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''aisisma''' |- | align="right" | 3, ''yawan'' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''daukisa''' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''kaikisa''' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''pulisa''' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''aisisa''' |} {{miskito_note|The compound verbs '''wark takaia''' ''to work'' and '''lan takaia''' ''to learn'' are formed from the borrowings from English '''wark''' ("work") and '''lan''' ("learn") and the Miskito verb '''takaia'''. Used as a simple verb, '''takaia''' means "go out, come out".}}
==The future tense== {{miskito_model| * Yauhka dia '''daukaisma'''? — Miskitu bila lan '''takaisna'''. * Yaptiki sap ra dimaisa bara yang witin wal sap ra '''dimaisna'''. * Man sap ra dia '''atkaisma'''? Yang mangu kum kum '''atkaisna'''. * Buk kum sin '''atkaisma''' ki? — Apia, yaptiki buk kum nahwala atkan. * Man aisiki ra ahkia '''kaikaisma'''? — Tisku '''kaikaisna''', bara witin wal '''aisaisna'''. * Prias watla ra ningkara '''dimaisna'''. * Man anira '''iwaisma''' ki? — Mairin nani wala ba wal '''iwaisna'''. | * What '''are you going to do''' tomorrow? — '''I am going to study''' (the) Miskito (language). * My mother will go into the shop and '''I will go in''' with her. * What '''are you going to buy''' in the shop? — '''I am going to buy''' some mangoes. * '''Are you going to buy''' a book too? — No, my mother bought a book yesterday. * When '''are you going to see''' my father? — '''I will see''' him soon, and then '''I will speak''' with him. * '''I will go into''' the church afterwards. * Where '''will you sit'''? — '''I will sit''' with the other women. }} {{miskito_mini_exercise|Answer the questions using the time words given: | # Ahkia balaisma? (yauhka) # Truk kum ahkia atkaisma? (tisku) # Aisikam ba yang wal ahkia aisaisa? (ningkara) # Ahkia utla ra kaisma? (yauhka) # Yawan ahkia takaisa? (ningkara) # Tuktikam ahkia kaikaisna? (tisku pali) # Witin nani skul ra ahkia dimaisa? (yauhka) | # Yauhka balaisna. # (Truk kum) tisku atkaisna. # Man wal ningkara aisaisa. # Yauhka kaisna. # Yawan ningkara takaisa. # Tisku pali kaikaisma. # Witin nani skul ra yauhka dimaisa. }} {{miskito_comment|The endings of the future tense are similar to those of the present, but begin with ''ai'' rather than ''i''. Another way to produce the future is to remove the final ''-a'' from the infinitive and add, in its place, the present-tense forms of '''kaia''', thus '''daukaia → daukai- → daukaisna, daukaisma, daukaisa'''. Compare the present and the future of '''daukaia''':}} {| cellspacing=0 cellpadding=6 align="center" | | PRESENT | FUTURE |- | align="right" | 1 | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''daukisna''' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''daukaisna''' |- | align="right" | 2 | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''daukisma''' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''daukaisma''' |- | align="right" | 3, ''yawan'' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''daukisa''' | align="center" bgcolor="#ecf3f7" | '''daukaisa''' |} {{miskito_note|'''Miskitu bila''' ''the Miskito language, Miskito'' is a compound noun formed from '''Miskitu''' and '''bila''', which basically means "mouth" but also "language" (and numerous other meanings, to be seen later).}} {{miskito_note|'''Bara''' is commonly used as a connecting word to mean "and then", "and so", or just "and". (Not to be confused with '''bara sa''' ''there is/are'', '''bara kan''' ''there was/were'', '''bara kaisa''' ''there will be''.)}}
==Vocabulary and review== {|width=100% style="background:#DEE7F5;" border="0" | colspan=3|{{Miskito_vocab_head| }} |- | width=33% valign="top"| {{miskito_vocab|ahkia|adv|when|7#The future tense}} {{miskito_vocab|atkaia|v|buy|7#The future tense}} {{miskito_vocab|baman|adv|only|7#The present tense}} {{miskito_vocab|bara|con|and then, and so|7#The present tense}} {{miskito_vocab|dimaia|v|go in, enter|7#The future tense}} | width=33% valign="top"| {{miskito_vocab|Inglis|n|English|7#The present tense}} {{miskito_vocab|Ispail|n|Spanish|7#The present tense}} {{miskito_vocab|lan takaia|cpd v|to learn|7#The present tense}} {{miskito_vocab|man|pron|you|7#I am}} {{miskito_vocab|Miskitu bila|cpd n|Miskito (language)|7#The present tense}} | width=33% valign="top"| {{miskito_vocab|pain|adv|well|7#The present tense}} {{miskito_vocab|takaia|v|go out|7#The present tense}} {{miskito_vocab|tisku|adv|soon|7#The future tense}} {{miskito_vocab|walaia|v|hear|7#The present tense}} {{miskito_vocab|wark takaia|cpd v|to work|7#The present tense}} |} {|width=100% style="background:#DEE7F5;" border="0" cellpadding="2" cellpadding="2" |{{Miskito_review_head|Choose one of the words given to complete the sentence.}} {{miskito_review|Yang utla ra yaptiki ra __________ munaisna.
(pain — hilp — wark)|Yang utla ra yaptiki ra hilp munaisna.}} {{miskito_review|Tibil ra buk kum __________ kaikisna.
(baman — bara — bila)|Tibil ra buk kum baman kaikisna.}} {{miskito_review|Yawan yauhka mangu kum kum __________.
(atkan — atkaisna — atkaisa)|Yawan yauhka mangu kum kum atkaisa.}} {{miskito_review|Miskitu bila pain lan __________.
(takisma — atkisma — inisma)|Miskitu bila pain lan takisma.}} {{miskito_review|Miriki na Miskitu bila lan takan __________ yawan wal pain aisisa.
(man — kum — bara)|Miriki na Miskitu bila lan takan bara yawan wal pain aisisa.}} |} {{miskito_nav|Lesson 6|Lesson 8}} [[Category:Miskito]]

revision.comment: New page: Hi, I'm new here, so if you could give me hand I'd be more than thankful. -W. L. Hennessey
revision.text:
Hi,
I'm new here, so if you could give me hand I'd be more than thankful.
-W. L. Hennessey

Hello and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]! Here are some tips to help you get started: * You should sign your name on Talk and vote pages using four tildes, like this: ~~~~. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * If you're a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]] to bring the material over in compliance with the GFDL. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[WB:SL|Staff Lounge]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun! You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Staff lounge|Staff lounge]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or ask me personally on my talk page. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be an idea if you add this page to your "watchlist" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. Good luck! --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 10:10, 4 February 2007 (UTC) == Cuisine of Suriname == G'day, nice to see someone building up the [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Suriname|Cuisine of Suriname]]! Are you planning on adding recipes for those dishes, or just basic descriptions of what they are? If you are planning on adding recipes, you might want to have a read of our [[Cookbook:Policy|Cookbook policy]] page, which outlines some basic formatting tips. I've created a category for these recipes to go into: [[:Category:Surinamese recipes]] (but please only add actual recipes to that category, not just meal descriptions). [[User:Webaware|Webaware]] [[User_talk:Webaware|talk]] 01:59, 6 February 2007 (UTC) == Pigment seeds == G'day, just checked out your recipe for [[Cookbook:Pastei|Pastei]] - very nice. I don't know what one of the ingredients is, however: pigment seeds. Is this some type of seed used for colouring the dish? Can you tell me what plant it is the seed from? Actually, I was also unsure about another ingredient: 1 fresh pepper. Does this mean: * [[Cookbook:Pepper|black peppercorn]]? * [[Cookbook:Bell Pepper|bell pepper]] (capsicum)? * [[Cookbook:Chili Pepper|chili pepper]]? cheers, [[User:Webaware|Webaware]] [[User_talk:Webaware|talk]] 21:37, 19 February 2007 (UTC) ==[[Cookbook:Pom]]== {{mbox|type=notice|msg= Thank you for your interest in Wikibooks, but [[Cookbook:Pom|this page]] appears as though it may have been created in error (such as due to a test or a misplaced edit). Should it be a legitimate [[WB:WIW|legitimate Wikibooks module]], please use [[{{TALKPAGENAME:Cookbook:Pom}}|the discussion page]] to explain its scope. If these concerns are not responded to, the page will automatically be considered a candidate for [[Wikibooks:Deletion policy#Speedy deletions|speedy deletion]] in 7 days. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 21:57, 14 April 2010 (UTC) }}

Hello and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]! Here are some tips to help you get started: * You should sign your name on Talk and vote pages using four tildes, like this: ~~~~. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * If you're a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]] to bring the material over in compliance with the GFDL. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[WB:SL|Staff Lounge]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun! You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Staff lounge|Staff lounge]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or ask me personally on my talk page. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be an idea if you add this page to your "watchlist" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. Good luck! --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 10:11, 4 February 2007 (UTC)

==Welcome!== [[Help:Welcome, newcomers|Welcome to Wikibooks]], a collection of open-content textbooks! You don't have to [[Special:Userlogin|log in]] to read or edit articles on Wikibooks, but creating an account is quick, free and non-intrusive, requires no personal information, and gives you many benefits, including: *The use of a username of your choice *The ability to view all your contributions via a "My contributions" link *Your own [[wikipedia:user page|user page]] *Your own talk page which, if you choose, also allows users to send you messages without knowing your e-mail address *The use of your own personal [[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]] to which you can add articles that interest you *The ability to rename pages. *The ability to [[Special:Upload|upload images]] *The ability to customize the appearance and behavior of the website *The eligibility to become an [[Help:Administrators|administrator]] *The right to be heard in votes and elections *Your IP address will no longer be visible to other users. We hope that you choose to become a Wikibookian and '''[[Special:Userlogin|create an account]]'''. Feel free to ask me any questions you may have on my talk page. By the way, make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes ('''~~~~'''), which will let others know who left it. --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 10:13, 4 February 2007 (UTC)
See: * [[:w:en:User:Peter Campbell]]

For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be an idea if you add this page to your "watchlist" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. Good luck! --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 10:39, 4 February 2007 (UTC) == I'm nosy! == Hi Peter - I checked out the wiki link and spotted the interest. As far as I can see I think it would be a very good idea indeed. There are one or two books on active pursuits but I don't think any of them are very active at present. Take a look around and get a feel for the place too - it is not like Wikipedia in many ways. Far smaller community for a start. If you have some content of WP it can be transwiki'd to preserve what there is (again check around the links). Certainly one issue is you will find far less wiki links here (I started placing them when I got here and had it pointed out to me!). If I can help let me know otherwise the [[WB:SL|Staff lounge]] is a good place for general queries. The book sounds good - cheers --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 10:57, 4 February 2007 (UTC)

revision.comment: /* Road terms */ some of this stuff does not work outside istanbul!
revision.text:
''Note: Under the paragraph "Road Terms", there is an unfinished list of vocabulary. Please add some more if you can.'' ''Not: "Road Terms" (Yol Sözcükler) paragrafında bir bitmemiş sözlük var. Eğer yapabiliyorsan, lütfen sözlüğe daha sözcükler ekle.'' Turkey is a very touristic place, and with so much to do there, one can easily get lost. Therefore, knowing how to ask for directions would be very useful. Whilst learning, take an opportunity to gaze into the highlights of Turkey (still adding new pictures!) ==Grammar== [[Image:Whirling Dervishes, Konya, Turkey, RMO.jpg|right|200px|thumb|Whirling dervishes in Konya. One would be amazed by both how beautiful the dance is and also the fact that they can somehow manage to spin around for so long without getting dizzy!]] Let's start with: '''Ben plaj''a'' nasıl gidebilirim?''' How can I get ''to'' the beach? Notice the italics in both of the sentences. When the letters '''a''' or '''e''' are added to the ends of nouns, that means the speaker is trying to get ''to''/give something ''to'' whatever the noun is, in this case, the beach. Let's look at some more examples of this: '''Ben ev''e'' gidiyorum.''' I'm going home. '''Sen okul''a'' gidiyorsun.''' You're going to school. '''O tatil''e'' gidiyor.''' He/she is going on holiday. When using proper nouns (such as city or country names), you must always add an apostrophe after the noun before adding '''a''' or '''e'''. For example: '''Biz Mısır'a gidiyoruz.''' We're going to Egypt. '''Siz İstanbul'a gidiyorsunuz.''' You (plural) are going to Istanbul. '''Onlar Londra'ya gidiyorlar.''' They're going to London. If you look at the last example, you'll notice that after '''Londra''', there was a '''ya''', rather than an '''a'''. '''Ya''' or '''ye''', rather than '''a''' or '''e''' respectively, are used when the noun ends with a vowel. For example: '''Ben Ankara'ya gidiyorum''' I'm going to Ankara. '''Sen Amerika'ya gidiyorsun''' You're going to America. '''O Tokyo'ya gidiyor''' He/she is going to Tokyo. OK, so know that we know the grammar of it all, let's move on to the main topic of this lesson: '''Asking for directions'''. ==Main topic== [[Image:Istanbul bridge.jpg|right|275px|thumb|Ah, Istanbul! So much to do there, but one can easily get lost!]] Let's start with our first question, and then build up into a proper conversation. You will probably be asking a stranger, therefore it is imperative to be polite and refer to him/her in the plural form: '''siz''' rather than '''sen'''. There are a few different ways of asking for directions in Turkish, all with almost literal translations into English: *'''Ben plaja nasıl ''giderim''?''' - How do I get to the beach? *'''Ben müzeye nasıl ''gidebilirim''?''' - How can I get to the museum? *'''Siz İzmir'e nasıl gidildiğini biliyor musunuz?''' - Do you know how to get to Izmir? Before you know how to engage in conversation with this person, it would be a good idea to actually learn how to say directions in Turkish. ===Directions=== *'''sol(a)''' - (to the) left *'''sağ(a)''' - (to the) right *'''ileri(ye)''' - (to the) forward *'''geri(ye)''' - (to the) backwards *'''Kuzey(e)''' - (to the) North *'''Güney(e)''' - (to the) South *'''Doğu(ya)''' - (to the) East *'''Batı(ya)''' - (to the) West *'''Kuzeydoğu(ya)''' - (to the) Northeast *'''Güneydoğu(ya)''' - (to the) Southeast *'''Güneybatı(ya)''' - (to the) Southwest *'''Kuzeybatı(ya)''' - (to the) Northwest ====More complex matters==== When you ask someone how to get to, say, the museum for example, they're not just going to say, ''"Go North!"''. It's most likely to be something much more complex, such as ''"As you go down the road, take the 2nd left turn, then at the next junction, take a right turn..."''. Below is some useful vocabulary which you will need to learn in order to understand what on Earth this stranger is telling you! Please note that Turkey uses the metric system, so they will most likely tell you distances in metres and kilometres rather than yards and miles. =====The metric system, in Turkish===== The terms are almost exactly the same as U.K. English, but not U.S. English. I have organized the vocabulary below into the following layout: '''Türkçe''' - ''U.K. English'' - U.S. English. :Note: don't forget that units preceded by a number do not take the plural as they do in English, so you never have to affix -ler or -lar when giving the number of meters, kilometers, and so on. Just the number. *'''milimetre''' - ''millimetre'' - millimeter *'''santimetre''' - ''centimetre'' - centimeter *'''metre''' - ''metre'' - meter *'''kilometre''' - ''kilometre'' - kilometer =====The imperial system, in Turkish===== It's unlikely that you'll ever use this vocab, but there may be instances where you will have to use the imperial system. So learn all these units, just in case... *'''inç''' - inch *'''ayak''' - foot (''ayak'' also means the actual body part) *'''yarda''' - yard *'''mil''' - mile =====Ordinal numbers===== You won't be able to know how to say ''"take your '''2nd''' left"'' without learning ordinal numbers in Turkish. For this section, I will use the following layout: bir'''inci''' - ''1.'' - 1st Rather than adding st's, nd's, rd's, or th's at the end of cardinal numbers to make them ordinal, in Turkish you simply add a full stop. Anyway, now that we know how to say '''1st''' in Turkish, let's learn the rest of them up to 10th. *iki'''nci''' - ''2.'' - 2nd *üç'''üncü''' - ''3.'' - 3rd *dörd'''üncü''' - ''4.'' - 4th (dört - four, dör'''t'''üncü becomes dör'''d'''üncü) *beş'''inci''' - ''5.'' - 5th *altı'''ncı''' - ''6.'' - 6th *yedi'''nci''' - ''7.'' - 7th *sekiz'''inci''' - ''8.'' - 8th *dokuz'''uncu''' - ''9.'' - 9th *on'''uncu''' - ''10.'' - 10th As you can see, when Turkish ordinal numbers are written out fully, they're just cardinal numbers with extra endings. This is true of all ordinal numbers after 10th, too. =====Road terms===== Now that you know the Turkish metric system and how to say Turkish ordinal numbers, let's learn the necessary vocab required. *'''yol''' - road *'''trafik''' - traffic *'''taşıma''' - transport *'''sokak / cadde''' - street / avenue *'''bulvar''' - boulevard *'''meydan''' - (town) square (''meydan'' literally means ''open space'', but can be translated as ''square''). *'''kestirme (yolu)''' - shortcut *'''otoban''' - highway *'''otoyol''' - motorway *'''şose''' - macadam *'''bisiklet yolu''' - bicycle path *'''raylar''' - rails *'''tünel''' - tunnel *'''köprü''' - bridge *'''viyadük''' - viaduct *'''kaldırım''' - pavement(it's a little bit confusing because it can also mean footpath) *'''patika''' - footpath *'''kavşak''' - junction *'''trafik ışıkları''' - traffic light *'''yol işaretleri''' - road signs *'''araba''' - car *'''tren''' - train *'''tramvay''' - tram *'''otobüs''' - bus *'''uçak''' - airplane *'''helikopter''' - helicopter *'''bisiklet''' - bicycle *'''motosiklet''' - motorcycle *'''taksi''' - taxi *'''gemi''' - boat *'''feribot''' - ferry *'''otobüs durağı''' - bus stop *'''demiryolu''' - railroad ===Getting to the point...=== [[Image:Grand Bazaar 03.JPG|right|275px|thumb|The hustle and bustle of Kapalicarsi, Istanbul. But in other areas, it's even more crowded!]] Well, I bet you're thinking, ''"Geez, it's about time!"'''. Well yes, but at least you've learnt all that's necessary in asking for directions. Now let's look at a typical conversation between '''t'''ourist and '''s'''tranger: '''T''': Ben müzeye nasıl gidebilirim? '''S''': İleri git, ve sağ tarafına dön. İkinci trafik ışığında sola döndüğünde meydanı görürsün. Karşıya gittiğinde, bulvarda yüz metre ileri sonra müzeyi bulursunuz. '''T''': Çok teşekkürler! '''S''': Birşey değil. Did you understand that? Didn't you? Either way, take a look at one of the boxes towards the bottom of the page for the translation of this conversation. ==Review== So what have we learnt this lesson? We have learnt: *Some grammar (adding ''a'', ''e'', etc. to the end of nouns). *Different ways of asking for directions. *How to say certain directions in Turkish. *How to say the units of the metric system in Turkish. *Turkish ordinal numbers. *Certain Turkish road terms. AND MOST IMPORTANTLY *How to ask for directions! [http://www.seslisozluk.com/tools/turkish_phrases Common Turkish phrases]
The translated conversation
{| style="width:100%; border-width:0px 1px 1px 1px; border-color:#aaaaaa; border-style:solid" ! Speaker || Translation |- | '''T''' || How can I get to the museum? |- | '''S''' || Go forward, and turn right. As you turn left at the second traffic light you will see the town square. When you've gotten across, if you go one hundred metres down the boulevard you will find the museum. |- | '''T''' || Thank you very much! |- | '''S''' || It was nothing. |}
{{Turkish/TOC}}
Also a user of Wikipedia - check warinthepocket's profile http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User:Warinthepocket

revision.comment: /* AutoHotKey scripts for memoQ */ fixed link, moved page
revision.text:
[http://www.kilgray.com/kilgray/products/memoq?locale=en MemoQ] is an integrated localization/translation environment that optimizes the productivity of translation and localization. In the MemoQ ILE, all translation resources are only a mouse-click away resulting in an ergonomy never seen before.
MemoQ is designed to provide an optimal environment for translators and project managers, with useless keystrokes and file operations eliminated. It is a one-stop environment with every tool integrated in the most transparent manner.
MemoQ is an easy-to-use concept-oriented system. Although the look and feel is somewhat similar to that of [[CAT-Tools/DéjàVu X|Déjà Vu]], things like a semi-WYSIWYG translation grid, access to remote translation memories and term bases, a cutting-edge aligner and homogeneity analysis in the statistics module make it match the older brother.
==Wish list== [[/Wishlist/|MemoQ wish list]]: what users want to be implemented. Please add your request and your name.
==Activation== Common [[/Activation/|activation issues]] with MemoQ.
[[/Conflicts/|Conflicts]] with other software.
==Tips and Tricks== [[/Tips and Tricks/]] for working with MemoQ:
*[[/Tips and Tricks#Establishing the backup procedure for MemoQ|Establishing the backup procedure for MemoQ]]
*[[/Tips and Tricks#Purge older translations from the TM|Purge older translations from the TM]]
*[[/Tips and Tricks#Working with TTX files using MemoQ 2.0 - alternate workflow|Working with TTX files using MemoQ 2.0 - alternate workflow]]
*[[/Tips and Tricks#Translating a docx file (Word 2007) using MemoQ|Translating a docx file (Word 2007) using MemoQ]]
*[[/Tips and Tricks#Changing a TTX file source/target language using MemoQ 2.x and above|Changing a TTX file source/target language using MemoQ 2.x and above]]
*[[/Tips and Tricks#Showing spaces and other special characters|Showing spaces and other special characters]]
*[[/Tips and Tricks#Entering non-breaking spaces|Entering non-breaking spaces]]
*[[/Tips and Tricks#Getting rid of codes in Word documents|Getting rid of codes in Word documents]]
*[[/Tips and Tricks#Disable case conversions in "Translation Results"|Disable case conversions in "Translation Results"]]
*[[/Tips and Tricks#Filter out unwanted languages|Filter out unwanted languages]]
*[[/Tips and Tricks#Reducing increased size of RTF files converted from DOC format containing images|Reducing increased size of RTF files converted from DOC format containing images]]
*[[/Tips and Tricks#Using MemoQ postcardware and MemoQ Translator Pro (full version) on the same computer|Using MemoQ postcardware and MemoQ Translator Pro (full version) on the same computer]]
*[[/Tips and Tricks#Avoiding hangs when copying large blocks of source to target|Avoiding hangs when copying large blocks of source to target]]
*[[/Tips and Tricks#Using auto-translatables for number format conversion|Using auto-translatables for number format conversion]]
==FAQ== [[/FAQ|Frequently asked questions]]; installation and usage issues.
* [[/FAQ#Operating systems|Operating systems]]
* [[/FAQ#File formats|File formats]]
* [[/FAQ#Installation issues|Installation issues]]
* [[/FAQ#Miscellaneous|Miscellaneous]]
==AutoHotKey scripts for memoQ== [[CAT-Tools/MemoQ/AutoHotKey scripts for memoQ|AutoHotKey scripts for memoQ]]: Collection of user-created AHK scripts for memoQ.
{{BookCat}}

revision.text:
{{recipe}} ==Ingredients== * 4 tbsp. [[Cookbook:Oil|oil]] * Spices: ** 6 whole [[Cookbook:Cardamom|cardamom pods]] (use only the seeds, discard the shells) ** 2 tsp whole [[Cookbook:Coriander|coriander seeds]] (it's not too strong, so use plenty) ** ⅛ tsp ground [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] ** ¼ tsp whole [[Cookbook:Cumin|cumin seeds]] ** 1 [[Cookbook:Bay Leaf|bay leaf]] ** 1 clove [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], chopped * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], chopped (increase spices if using lots more onion, otherwise the taste is weak) * 2 lb fryer, or [[Cookbook:Chicken|chicken]] parts (OPTIONAL: substitute [[Cookbook:Tofu|firm tofu]] for the chicken.) * 1 cup [[Cookbook:Sour Cream|sour cream]] (or 1 cup plain [[Cookbook:Yogurt|yogurt]] & ½ cup sour cream) * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Currant|currants]] (or [[Cookbook:Raisin|raisins]], if currants are unavailable) ===Optional extras:=== * ¼-⅓ cup [[Cookbook:Almond|slivered almonds]] (toasted if you prefer) * 2 tbsp shredded (or chipped) [[Cookbook:Coconut|coconut]] (also toasted) ==Procedure== # Heat oil until quite hot (not smoking.) # Add spices and bay leaf. Cook until seeds crack. (1-2 minutes.) # Reduce heat. # Add garlic and onion. Cook until tender & translucent. # Reserve onion, garlic & spices into a side dish. # Season chicken with salt & pepper. Roll in flour. # Fry chicken. (Add oil if needed.) # When chicken is almost done, add reserved onion/spice mixture. # Add currants.
– At this point, chicken may be cooled & frozen. # To serve, add sour cream (or mixture of sour cream and yogurt) and simmer until chicken is tender and sauce has cooked down a little. # Serve with [[Cookbook:Saffron Sweet Rice|Saffron Sweet Rice]] ==Notes== *After cooking, the spices continue to infuse the chicken and mellow the flavor. Refrigerating this dish for a day then warming it, enhances its flavor! [[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

This book teaches Z80 Assembly Programming, a language used in the Texas Instruments TI-73x, TI-81, TI-82, TI-83x, TI-84x, TI-85, and TI-86 calculators. A modified version was also used in the production of the Nintendo Game Boy and Game Boy Color.
This book will provide instructions for programming, transferring, and executing an Assembly program on a Texas Instruments calculator. Note that only the TI-82 and above have a link cable to transfer files from your computer to the calculator, so the TI-73x and TI-81 cannot be used.
==Table of Contents==
===Getting Started===
{{Wikipedia|Zilog Z80}}
